I swore off Call of Duty games after black ops 2, back when they still had Martyrdom, which was a bigger contributor for me giving up on the franchise. But when i saw that i could buy black ops 3 starter pack for a very low price, i thought that i would give it a try and see if i would enjoy it better after years of the company having a chance to improve their games. I honestly don't know what the hell i was thinking at all. The game suffers from a lot of the same issues that has been plaguing it since the ps3 days, terrible spawns, guns at times feeling completely overpowered, maps suffering from too many open doorways, you would check your flank before turning around to push up and as soon as you believe the coast is clear, someone comes from right where you just checked and flank you anyway!  And especially on PC the game feels like a mess, i mean when it works, it works pretty well, running smooth, but when it isn't working, you will suffer from lag and what seems to be FPS drops, and i run a pretty decent machine, having a 750 ti, 8gb of ram, and an i3, this game mostly allows you to have the graphics set to medium and it still lags so i know it is mostly a connection issue with the servers, which you guessed it, is another isssue that has been with the series since the beginning. At this point i am certain that the companies behind these Cod games are in it for the money, because if they really listened to its community then most of these issues wouldn't be a factor anymore. The game is still fun in its own way, and it can be addicting, but this franchise will appeal to some people who don't mind the flaws at all. But if you are going to buy this game, at least know exactly what you are buying before putting money into this.

Black ops 3 is a great game with an immense amount of content to keep you coming back:  Multiplayer: Has some nice features added. You can look at your weapons in 3D, there are flehed out specialist characters with their own lore. The supply drops are a waste of money and really annoying for people who don't buy them becuase there are guns your missing out on (luckily mods have you covered ;D). The maps are pretty ♥♥♥♥ besides Nuketown and combine, and the scorestreaks are a disgrace to the godly name they bare. 7/10  Zombies: Is very fun and much thought has been put into it. They first map is shadows of evil, and it is fantastic. While a bit complicated, the art is very nice and the gameplay is smooth. The rest of the maps are also pretty fun, bringing in new activities to do and guns to use. Mabye better than multiplayer? (oh ya and it has Giant remake).  Dead ops II: Its here for you to play as extra. Back on popular demand, its a nice some-what more arcady style of gameplay, but don't expect to get hours out of it. Its almost like a free DLC, but it came with the game from the start. Love Treyarch <3 10/10  Nightmare: Fun take on campaign. Not the most entertaining, but adds a twist to your usually gameplay, and will feel somewhat fresh. You get to fight zombies. 5/10  Free Run: Awesome addition that I cant imagine the game without. Lets you play around with controls and new movement, while giving some speed-run parkour maps. Didnt spend alot of time in it, but they were fun hours. 10/10  Mods: The mods aren't anything to drool at yet, but it takes time. So far there have been many custom maps that I have played and enjoyed. Guns, maps, and changes to rules. New ways to play zombies and many more additions to come. 10/10  Campaign: Oh... well i didnt really play it. Its there, definelty nice that they put it in to finish black ops trilogy. If only it had something to do with the previous games. Its like a dream sequence or something, I really don't know. But hey, theres online version of it now! 2/10  DLC: Unless your a zombies nerd, they arent worth it. It adds a couple multiplayer maps, but on PC no one has them so you can't play online. The zombies map is the real deal, but you'll have to dish out 15$. AND THEY DIDNT ADD ANY NEW PARKOUR MAPS ;( 2/10  Few things to let you know:  This is the first Call of Duty I have ever bought The only other call of dutys i played: BO multiplayer & zombies, BO2 multiplayer & zombies, MW2 multiplayer, and MW3 multiplayer. I like town, but only becuase it was the only map in BO2 i played. Had good memories with it.   Conclusion:  Its a really good call of duty, that definitly strives for more content. Of course, quality over content, but this really is quality. I enjoyed myself, and ca't wait for the new mods to be continually released

Note that I'm not big on multi-player for fps games, so this review will pertain primarily to the story and technical aspects of Black Ops 3. Though I will get around to updating about the zombie horde mode. That said.  One belief I have is a game should be able to stand up on just it's single player alone. Black Ops 3 manages this, a bit wobbly in some spots, but stands solid for the most part. The story picks up some time after the events of Black Ops 2 and contains story content from the first two games that feel organic to the story, if the story made any real sense. The pieces all fit like a warped jigsaw puzzle, with funky exposition the player can feel lost for a majority of the story. Whether this is intentional or not, I leave to the subjective side of things. But otherwise the game continues the underlying narrative of how the mind is affected in warfare and the advantages and disadvantages of technologies role in both the public and private worlds. Though cliche, the story manages to not lose itself entirely to entire levels set in a surreal reality muddled with pseudo-science.  On the technical side, the game performed quite well. With only two real hiccups which consist of an entirely random ctd and one game breaking glitch which in which the AI seemed to forget just what it was doing. Frame drops only occured in a small handful of areas which quickly stopped after seconds. However the user interface feels very much designed for console without being reworked for a mouse and keyboard setup which ruins the pacing throughout the game. The in combat menu to select your special abilites is designed for analog stick controllers, wasting precious seconds in the heat of combat to choose an ability. As for combat itself, this honestly feels like a game that just happens to have the Call of Duty IP attached to it.  Overall, the single player campaign feels good. Not entirely worth a full price of $60, but good enough to catch on sale if multi-player isn't your bag and you want a good fairly solid shooter. I will say, the campaign feels like it should have a fair amount of replay value as Black Ops 3 also continues giving the player the ability to choose their loadouts before each mission, customize weapons and abilities as well.  Pros: -Solid single player -Great graphics -Performs pretty good -Campaign feels lengthy -Proper difficulty curve  Cons: -Bad user interface, needs to be modified for PC mouse and keyboard -Massive file size for vanilla game -AI can feel janky at times  PC specs for comparison: MSI MS-7850 Intel Core i5-4670k CPU @ 3.40GHz overclocked at 4.3GHz 12299MB RAM (12GB RAM) EVGA Nvidia GeForce GTX 960 4GB ftw edition resolution @ 1920x1080  Game was played at optimal preferences according to GeForce experience, in game settings of high
